headline.main: Uranium Mines In West Leave Deadly Legacy; Uranium Mines Leaving Legacy of Death for Indians

docs.abstract: Uranium miners in New Mexico, Arizona and Colorado and Utah, many of them from Navajo reservation, are showing alarming increase in death from lung cancer and pulmonary fibrosis, which Government and private doctors attribute to radioactive radon gas and its offspring, 'radon daughters,' found in uranium mines; Kerr-McGee Corp, which operated mines at Red Rock and Cove, Ariz, between '52 and '63, says it doubts link between radiation exposure and disease, some people accuse company of cleaning up mines only when Federal inspectors arrived; focus of mining has since moved to area around Grants, NM, and most of workers are now white; better enforcement of exposure rules since '72 is said to have reduced cancer risk considerably; efforts to get help for all ailing miners have so far been ineffective; Dr Joseph Wagoner (OSHA), Dr Victor Archer (Public Health Service) and Dr LaVerne Husen comment; Husen illus; illus of Indian woman (M)

byline.original: By MOLLY IVINS Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: RED ROCK, Ariz.--The Great Galleon Rock, after which Shiprock, N.M., is named, floats against the sky just a few miles from here, like a fantastic cathedral, a dream of grace and hope.
docs.snippet: RED ROCK, Ariz.--The Great Galleon Rock, after which Shiprock, N.M., is named, floats against the sky just a few miles from here, like a fantastic cathedral, a dream of grace and hope.

headline.main: County Exceeds State In Cancer Death Rate

docs.abstract: Article on high cancer-death rate in Westchester County, NY; discusses variety of environmental and sociological factors (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: CANCER deaths have risen faster in Westchester County than in the region or the state as a whole in the last several years, according to figures released recently by the New York State Department of Health.
docs.snippet: CANCER deaths have risen faster in Westchester County than in the region or the state as a whole in the last several  years, according to figures released recently by the New York State Department of Health.

docs.abstract: J Reston article says nation's gasoline shortages are being perceived as worse than they are because of lack of trust among people in leadership of their institutions and in one another
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 15--Nothing fundamental has changed in this country in the last few weeks, but suddenly the mood seems different: more confused, quarrelsome and pessimistic.
docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, May 15--Nothing fundamental has changed in this country in the last few weeks, but suddenly the mood seems different: more confused, quarrelsome and pessimistic.
